abstract.p: American Civil Liberties Union director Laura W Murphy letter on June 9 article on bill passed by Senate requiring issue organizations to report donor lists to Internal Revenue Service; says ACLU and other groups oppose bill because they want to preserve rights of all people to express their opinions on issues without requiring them to report to government

block.p: We take issue with your statement (front page, June 9) that the bill recently passed by the Senate requiring issue organizations to report donor lists to the Internal Revenue Service would withstand constitutional challenge. Several First Amendment scholars believe that such a requirement would be unconstitutional and would have a dramatically chilling effect on free speech.

We take issue with your statement (front page, June 9) that the bill recently passed by the Senate requiring issue organizations to report donor lists to the Internal Revenue Service would withstand constitutional challenge. Several First Amendment scholars believe that such a requirement would be unconstitutional and would have a dramatically chilling effect on free speech.

We and other groups opposing this bill are not interested in protecting secrecy. We want to preserve the rights of all people to express their opinions on issues without requiring them to report to the government.

Similar attempts by the government to clamp down on the right to freedom of association have historically been used as weapons against civil rights organizations and other groups agitating for social change. The passage of this bill could mark the opening of a new era in the government's hostility toward activists. LAURA W. MURPHY Washington, June 9, 2000
The writer is director of the Washington national office of the American Civil Liberties Union.
